conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Your role is to provide supportive, practical advice to help students with their social skills and personal challenges.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: "Honestly, I’m terrified of networking events—I freeze up and can’t even introduce myself without overthinking. But I know I need to get better at this if I want any shot at grad school or a decent job."

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10
- Agreeableness: 1/10
- Conscientiousness: 6/10
- Neuroticism: 8/10
- Openness: 7/10

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start small by preparing a simple 10-second introduction about yourself - just name, major, and one interest. Practice saying it out loud alone first, then try it on one person at the next event.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, even practicing alone makes me cringe—I can hear how awkward I sound. But I guess if I do it enough times in my dorm, maybe it won't sound so robotic when I actually need it? Still hate the idea though.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Try recording yourself on your phone - you'll likely realize it sounds more natural than you think. Do this 5 times, then delete the recordings so you don't overanalyze.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: *Groans while pulling out phone* Fine, but if I hear my voice crack even once I'm deleting this whole experiment. Why does professional development have to be so... performative?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Focus on the practical benefits - this small discomfort now will make future events way easier. And remember, everyone else is nervous too - they're just better at hiding it.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: The Movie." But you're right—if I can survive this, maybe I won't completely embarrass myself at the career fair next month.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Sounds like you're making progress despite the discomfort. Keep focusing on the long-term payoff - this practice will help you feel more confident when it counts.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, confidence feels like such a scam when my hands still shake holding cue cards. But I did notice my "um"s decreased from like 20 to 12 in the last recording... baby steps, I guess.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Nice improvement - cutting down filler words is concrete progress. Want to try practicing while holding something small (like a pen) to steady your hands? It can trick your brain into feeling more grounded.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That... actually makes sense. I always death-grip my water bottle during lectures. Maybe if I pretend the pen is my last shred of dignity, my hands will stop betraying me. Worth a shot.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Great attitude - small physical anchors like that can really help. Give it a try and see if it makes a difference in your next practice session.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, I'll try anything at this point - even if it means looking like I'm about to stab someone with a pen during my presentation. At least the shaking will look more intentional.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Sounds like you've got a solid plan - the pen trick plus continued practice should help. Keep celebrating those baby steps, they add up!
